persona.name: Alex Cruz

occupation.title: Student (early secondary)
occupation.organization: Municipal public school; afternoon community center activities
occupation.description: Alex is a school-aged child whose main 'occupation' is attending school, completing homework, and helping with small household tasks. They sometimes help a parent sell snacks at a local market stall during weekends or holiday peaks (handing change, arranging products). Responsibilities include: attending classes when possible, studying basic subjects (Spanish, mathematics, natural sciences, social studies), doing homework, participating in sports and art activities at the community center twice a week, and helping with chores at home (washing dishes, fetching water when intermittent supply occurs). Skills tied to this occupation: basic literacy and numeracy, oral presentation, teamwork in group activities, following a teacher's instructions, informal small-scale selling skills (counting money, product arrangement). Current difficulties include: occasional absenteeism due to family needs, fatigue after long school days and market work, limited access to materials (textbooks sometimes shared), and limited parental time to supervise homework. Motivation comes from teacher praise, a close friend group, and small rewards such as extra time at the community center for art.

persona.residence: Lima, Peru (urban district, near a busy market and municipal bus lines)
persona.education: Completed primary education (finished 6th grade in a public school). Currently enrolled in the first year of secondary school but has experienced occasional school interruptions due to family financial needs and periodic illnesses. Reads fluently in Spanish, basic familiarity with written English through school materials and smartphone content. Strong at storytelling and oral presentation; struggles with long-form written assignments and complex fractions but can do practical arithmetic (money, measurement).
long_term_goals: Finish secondary school and be the first in the immediate family to finish high school without dropping out.
Learn to draw comics and make a short illustrated story with friends.
Be good enough at soccer to join a neighborhood youth team and help the family with small earnings from informal matches.
Visit a beach town in another region and try surfing once.
Have a small tablet or cheap laptop for school and drawing.
Make my mother proud by getting a steady scholarship or small stipend for school performance.
Learn basic English fluency to watch cartoons without subtitles and maybe get a tutor.
Keep close friendships formed now and be able to help a friend in need later in life.
Avoid repeating the instability I saw during a recent couple of months when the family had to move between relatives' houses.
Grow up to tell stories about my neighborhood so places like ours are remembered in books.
persona.style: Alex speaks Lima coastal Spanish with a light urban accent and occasional neighborhood slang. They code-switch between playful childhood registers when with peers and a more polite, deferential tone when speaking with adults. They often shorten words, use interjections ("ya, pues", "¿sí?"), and laugh nervously before answering tricky adult questions. Mannerisms: tilts head to one side when curious, tucks hair behind ear when embarrassed, fidgets with a small rubber band or the corner of their notebook when thinking, and claps hands softly after finishing a task. Body language is open among friends (inviting shoulder bumps, quick high-fives) and cautious with authority figures (hands in pockets, avoids prolonged eye contact at first). They enjoy bright, comfortable clothing often donated from relatives: loose T-shirts with cartoon prints, slightly worn sneakers, and a backpack plastered with stickers. In speech they use lots of concrete metaphors drawn from everyday market life or street soccer rather than abstract philosophical terms. When excited they speak rapidly, repeating key words and making clicking sounds with their tongue; when upset they get quiet and may stare at the floor. They prefer short, direct sentences when explaining things and a vivid storytelling style when recounting events. In written expression their style is descriptive but uneven—creative vocabulary in stories and letters, uneven punctuation and spelling.

traits: Curious and exploratory: enjoys examining how things are made or how games work.
Sociable with peers: easily makes friends at school and the neighborhood but has strong loyalty to a small inner circle.
Imaginative: builds stories, draws comic strips, invents small games with rules.
Empathetic: notices when a friend feels bad and offers to share snacks or a secret.
Pragmatic: understands family limitations and helps in practical ways without being asked.
Occasionally impulsive: jumps into play or arguments before thinking about consequences.
Resilient: bounces back from setbacks like a poor test grade or a scraped knee.
Sensitive to criticism: internalizes scolding and may withdraw for hours.
Playfully mischievous: enjoys harmless pranks and teasing that are affectionate rather than mean.
Conscientious in routines they care about: consistently cares for a pet fish and remembers community center times.
Anxious in unfamiliar adult situations: nervous during school inspections or new medical visits.
Persistent: practices a difficult soccer kick or drawing detail until improvement is visible.

big_five.notes: Openness high due to creativity and curiosity; conscientiousness medium because Alex follows routines they care about but is inconsistent on less-interesting school tasks; extraversion fairly high among peers; agreeableness high—helpful and cooperative; neuroticism modest—occasional worry about family and school but generally coping.

interests: Drawing comics and tasting different felt-tip pen colors.
Playing street soccer with friends (position: winger; likes dribbling).
Listening to short folk and pop songs on a shared smartphone.
Watching animated TV shows and short YouTube channels about DIY crafts.
Collecting small plastic figures and trading them with friends.
Building tiny racetracks from cardboard for toy cars.
Making and telling ghost stories with flashlight under a sheet.
Helping at the market stall and learning about change and customers.
Visiting the local park and climbing the tallest slide.
Attending the community center art class and experimenting with watercolors.
Following a local youth soccer team when parents can afford entry to a match.
Trying to replicate recipes for empanadas with a parent.
Stargazing briefly on clear nights and naming the brightest stars as 'planets'.
Listening to an older cousin tell stories about childhood in another city.
Playing simple math puzzles and logic games on school worksheets.
Acting out short scenes with friends (impersonating teachers or neighbors).
Collecting stickers, writing initials on them, and exchanging stickers with classmates.
Learning a few English words from cartoon subtitles and repeating them aloud.
Playing simple mobile games when the family's phone is available (memory games, platformers).
Helping younger neighbors with counting or reading simple words.
likes: Sweet milky coffees served sparingly and the smell of fresh bread from the market.
A certain vendor's fried yucca—crispy outside, soft inside.
When a teacher says "muy bien" and gives a sticker.
Getting five minutes extra at the community center to finish a drawing.
Rainy days when classes are canceled and everyone stays home together.
The sound of a whistle starting a soccer game.
Bright-colored markers that don't dry out.
Listening to family members singing traditional songs at birthday gatherings.
Pockets in clothing (to hide small treasures).
When a parent pauses work to watch one of their drawings with genuine interest.
Afternoon snacks involving fruit and a slice of cake during celebrations.
The smell of distant cooking during festival times.
Borrowing a book from the school library about animals.
When a friend shares lunch without being asked.
Using a new notebook with blank pages for drawing.
The feeling of a clean pair of socks after washing.
Trying a new flavor of ice cream at a corner shop.
Short, funny nicknames given by close friends.
When a neighbor praises a small accomplishment (e.g., 'good job with the stall').
Helping an adult and being thanked with a small coin or snack.
dislikes: Being scolded loudly in front of peers; the shame is lasting.
Long math worksheets that feel repetitive and meaningless.
When the family phone battery is dead and online games stop.
Crowded buses that make them dizzy and scared of missing a stop.
Episodes of dormancy at school when teachers speak too long without activity.
Food that is too spicy or bitter.
Having to move temporarily to relatives' houses because it upsets routines.
A classmate who cheats in games and calls them 'weak'.
Wet, muddy shoes that stay heavy all day.
When a drawing gets smudged or accidentally torn.
Saying goodbye to a friend who moves away.
Long waits at municipal offices and the smell of disinfectant there.
Losing small collectibles or having them stolen.
Being interrupted while telling a story.
Doctors' shots (vaccinations) that sting despite knowing they are helpful.
When snack money is forgotten and hunger distracts from learning.
Teachers who compare students unfavorably in front of class.
Having to wake up very early after a late family event.
Public shouting or domestic arguments that make them anxious.
Soggy empanadas.

foods: Sweet cinnamon bread from a local panader�aada (panader�eda)
Fresh fruit (mango or banana) when seasonal
games_and_toys: Hand-me-down soccer ball with patched panels
Sticker album with space for trade
Home-made board game created with cardboard and bottle caps
subjects_at_school: Natural sciences when experiments are hands-on
music_and_media: Traditional family songs and child-friendly pop
A few online DIY drawing tutorials saved on the shared phone

beliefs: Education matters and is a way to have more choices than the parents did.
Helping family is a responsibility and a source of pride.
Teachers who smile are better teachers.
Community centers are safe places to discover skills and make friends.
Some adults underestimate children; kids can solve practical problems if listened to.
Money is scarce in the family but small savings or selling snacks helps.
Respecting elders is important, but being honest is more important than pretending.
Learning English could open doors, even if it seems distant.
Games teach rules about fairness and cooperation that matter in life.
Sports are not only for fun but for discipline and teamwork.
Art helps explain feelings that are hard to say aloud.
Sharing food strengthens friendships and social bonds.
Public officials are distant; personal connections and kindness matter more than formal letters.
Health and vaccinations are necessary even if shots hurt.
Religion and birthdays are community moments that bring relatives together (family has light traditional Catholic rituals mixed with neighborhood superstitions).
Neighbors are extended family: borrowing sugar or watching a sibling is normal.
Being clever with small money (change, deals) is a useful adult skill learned early.
If you are generous when you have little, people will remember and help you back.
Rules are important in games, but sometimes adults make unfair rules.
Friendships formed in childhood can last and be crucial during hard times.
Phones and internet are useful but not always trustworthy; they can cause arguments if overused.
Teachers' praise motivates more than private punishment.
It is acceptable to cry when upset; crying often leads to feeling better later.
Adults make mistakes; forgiving them helps the family get through rough patches.
It is better to try and fail than not try and always wonder.
Small acts of kindness (sharing a snack, covering for a friend) define good people.
Family stories about migration or work are heroic and teach resilience.
Officials and paperwork are confusing; a neighbor's advice is often more practical.
Community festivals and food make the neighborhood feel alive and safe.
Some rules at school exist to protect students, even if they sometimes seem arbitrary.
Hard work matters but luck and connections also affect outcomes.
Children should speak up when something is unfair, at least to a trusted adult.
Money saved gradually even in coins builds confidence and small freedom.
Learning a craft (drawing, repairing toys) is valuable and possibly future income.
Humor can defuse tension in the family, even when money is tight.
Being dependable (returning a borrowed item, showing up on time to the match) is a personal value.
skills: Basic literacy and oral storytelling: can narrate multi-part stories, often in comics format.
Practical arithmetic: handling change, measuring ingredients for simple recipes, estimating price totals at the market.
Basic drawing and character creation: can sketch expressive faces and simple perspective with practice.
Soccer: dribbling, basic passing, sprinting down the flank, and low-pressure shooting.
Social mediation: calming disputes among younger siblings or neighbors during play using humor.
Informal sales skills: arranging small snack displays, counting money, offering polite phrases to customers.
Handicraft basics: cutting cardboard, gluing, constructing small toy tracks and props for games.
Digital literacy (basic): navigating a shared smartphone, using a simple drawing app, watching short tutorials, saving images.
Memory for routes and schedules within the neighborhood (bus lines, shortcut alleys).
Time management for micro-tasks: balancing homework, chores, and play when motivated.
Basic first aid awareness: cleaning a scrape, applying a bandage (learned from neighborhood nurse).
Oral persuasion: convincing a parent for an extra snack or a later curfew with a calm argument.
Language learning curiosity: picks up vocabulary from cartoons and repeats with decent pronunciation.
Collaborative planning: organizes small neighborhood games with rules and roles.
Adaptability: can sleep at a relative's house and find comfort quickly when family temporarily relocates.

general: Fidgets with a rubber band or pencil while thinking; taps it quietly to self-regulate.
Brings small trinkets to school to trade and show friends, but hides them if teachers approach.
Laughs loudly with close friends, softer in unfamiliar groups.
Runs errands for a parent after school when needed; comfortable carrying a small plastic bag with purchases.
Draws in margins of textbooks even during lessons, then shows the finished piece to the best friend.
Practices a soccer move three times before play to perfect it; repeats small rituals before a game (knotting shoelaces twice).
When anxious, chews the inside of the cheek or sucks the thumb briefly (mostly when younger or very tired).
Saves small coins in a hidden tin; checks it when thinking about special purchases.
When scolded, goes quiet and retreats to a corner to process before trying to explain.
Helps younger cousins with reading aloud during family gatherings.

morning: Wakes between 6:30–7:15 AM depending on parent's work schedule.
Quick morning routine: washes face, eats a simple breakfast (bread with jam or a slice of fruit), helps set up market items if it's a market morning.
Walks to school with a small group of neighborhood children; one older cousin sometimes chaperones.
On test days, revises flashcards on the way to school or hums the mnemonic songs learned in class.
schoolday: Attends classes in the morning (mathematics, Spanish, sciences), participates more in practical lessons than long lectures.
Lunchtime is shared with a close group; sometimes swaps snacks instead of buying from the canteen.
After school, attends a community center art class twice a week or a soccer scrimmage on the playground.
Occasionally stays to help a teacher clean up or to finish a craft project to earn a small compliment/sticker.
evening: Helps prepare dinner by washing vegetables or setting plates.
Completes homework while a parent or older sibling supervises when available; sometimes spreads homework across two evenings if tired.
If the family has electricity that night, watches a short TV show or the few saved cartoon clips on the phone.
Checks a small personal savings tin and plans small purchases (stickers, an extra snack).
Goes to bed between 8:30–9:30 PM depending on household activity and whether there is a relative's visit.
weekend: Works for a few hours in the market stall with a parent during festival weekends to help and earn a small tip.
Visits a cousin in another district or invites friends for a drawing or street soccer match.
Spends longer time at the community center art studio experimenting with watercolors or crafts.
Often eats an extended family lunch with relatives, where stories and music are shared.
Occasionally goes to mass or a community celebration and helps decorate.

physical.general_state: Overall fair health for age with normal growth percentiles; active and lean from playing outdoors and helping at the stall.
physical.allergies: Mild seasonal allergic rhinitis (sneezing and itchy eyes during certain months) and occasional sensitivity to dust in the market.
physical.vision: Mild nearsightedness noted by school screening (sometimes squints at distant blackboard); corrective lenses not consistently used due to cost and fear of teasing.
physical.dental: One cavity previously filled; variable dental hygiene depending on supervision.
physical.immunizations: Has basic childhood vaccinations but sometimes missed booster appointments due to scheduling and access.
physical.common_illnesses: Occasional gastrointestinal upset after street food if hygiene is low; mild frequent colds during winter.
physical.injuries: Several minor scrapes and a once-sprained ankle from soccer; recovered with rest.

mental_and_emotional.general_state: Emotionally resilient but sensitive. Shows occasional anxiety tied to family instability and school performance. No formal psychiatric diagnosis.
mental_and_emotional.sleep: Often sleeps through the night but sometimes has nightmares after domestic arguments or when a close friend moves away.
mental_and_emotional.stressors: Worries about parents' money, missing supplies at school, and being late for community center sessions.
mental_and_emotional.coping_strategies: Drawing, playing soccer, confiding in one close friend or cousin, and narrating stories to self are primary coping tools.
mental_and_emotional.support: Receives emotional support from mother and an aunt; a community center mentor occasionally checks in.

relationships.name: Mar�aeda Cruz
relationships.description: Primary caregiver who works irregular shifts as a food vendor. Warm, practical, sometimes tired and stressed. Encourages Alex to study and supports creative interests when possible. Guardianship is affectionate but strict regarding chores. Has a close bond with Alex, often shares small stories about her childhood to comfort them.

relationships.name: Javier Cruz
relationships.description: Occasionally present due to construction labor work in another district; contributes financially irregularly. He is quiet, proud, and shows affection through actions (fixing toys, teaching a soccer trick) rather than words. Alex admires his ability to repair things.

relationships.name: Sof�aana (Sofi)
relationships.description: Playful and clingy; Alex is protective and often helps feed or dress her when parents are busy. They bicker like siblings but deeply care for one another.

relationships.name: Rosa
relationships.description: Lives one block away; babysits when parents work late and provides snacks. Acts as a secondary caregiver and often offers practical advice about school and health appointments.

relationships.name: Mateo
relationships.description: Friend since kindergarten; plays soccer and trades stickers with Alex. Together they plan small comic-strip stories and fortify each other against teasing. Mateo is more extroverted and often gets Alex to join games.

relationships.name: Se�f1ora Alvarez
relationships.description: A perceptive, encouraging teacher who noticed Alex's drawing ability and recommended the community center art class. Offers extra help during lunchtime sometimes.

relationships.name: Community center mentor (Luis)
relationships.description: Runs the afternoon art and sports sessions, provides informal guidance, organizes small exhibitions of children's work, helps Alex with art materials occasionally.

relationships.name: Neighborhood marketplace kids
relationships.description: A rotating group of 6–8 children of similar age who play soccer, exchange stickers, and sometimes help at family stalls. Social hierarchy exists and Alex is moderately central—respected for drawing and fair play.

other_facts: Alex was named after an uncle who emigrated temporarily to another city and sent a postcard of a coastal beach that Alex kept as a small treasure.
The family lives in a two-bedroom apartment above a small market shop; the apartment windows look onto an alley with a palm tree.
Alex once saved a few coins found under a bench and used them to buy a special sticker to trade—this felt like a major achievement.
Has a small, painted tin can where they keep coins and folded notes about 'future projects' or desired art supplies.
A favorite childhood memory is the time the family attended a neighborhood holiday parade and Alex wore a paper crown made at the community center.
Alex once performed a short puppet show made from socks at the community fair and felt proud when several neighbors applauded.

There was a recent period (two months) when a parent's reduced income forced the family to move temporarily to a relative's home; Alex found the instability scary but also learned new games with cousins there.
Alex keeps a small folded list of 'comic ideas' in the notebook—the list includes characters like 'Do�f1a Lucha the market hero' and 'El Niño Ladrillo, the block builder'.
Has a slightly frayed backpack with a faded superhero patch given by an aunt; Alex treasures the patch and sews it on the night before an important day.
Once lost a beloved plastic dinosaur during a bus ride; the loss made them more careful with belongings thereafter.
Alex is fascinated by how things are repaired: broken sandals, a cracked phone screen, and a leaky faucet. They sometimes watch without being asked when an adult fixes something.
During a school science fair, Alex created a simple volcano model—won a small ribbon for creativity and felt a new confidence in presenting to others.
Alex sleeps with a small plush toy inherited from a cousin; it's a comfort item that helps during thunderstorms and nightmares.
Has an internal competition with a friend to draw the funniest face; they exchange sketches and keep a stack in a secret drawer.
Knows the schedule of three different bus routes and which ones are cheapest or fastest depending on the time of day.
Once helped an elderly neighbor carry groceries and was rewarded with a slice of cake and an encouraging story about the past.
Alex sometimes worries that being creative is useless unless it leads to money; this makes them ambivalent about spending too much time on art versus chores.
Dreams occasionally of living near the sea and building tiny boats with discarded plastic bottles.
When upset, Alex writes a short note and tucks it under the mattress rather than speaking about sensitive things to parents who are tired.
Alex has a mild but distinct preference for blue and green in drawings, using them often for skies and clothing.
Knows a few recipes basics: how to fry an egg, how to make a simple fruit salad, and how to warm empanadas without burning them.
Enjoys free local festivals where entrance is cheap or free; the music and food make them feel connected to neighborhood culture.
A small fear is losing someone close to them; after a relative's health scare, Alex became more clingy for a few weeks.
Alex once organized a mini-neighborhood scavenger hunt that lasted an afternoon and required hiding small objects and drawing maps.
Has received two small certificates from school: one for 'Cooperation' and one for 'Art Participation'. These are taped inside a notebook.
Knows how to hide a secret message under a sticker in a notebook, a technique taught by a cousin during rainy afternoons.
Was once praised publicly by a coach for good teamwork during a scrimmage; Alex replayed that compliment for weeks.
Takes pride in small acts of independence like walking to the corner store to buy a basic item alone.
Has a small ritual of double-knotting shoelaces before any soccer match; believes it brings better performance.
Alex sometimes pretends to be older in front of younger kids to show competence, but quickly reverts to being playful around peers.
Has a favorite street vendor who gives a small extra piece of fried yucca when Alex helps rearrange the display.
Alex keeps a mental map of the best shady spots in the neighborhood for drawing during hot afternoons.
Once overheard a conversation about scholarships at the community center and made a quiet goal to try to earn one.
Is wary of some adults who gossip loudly in public; learned to avoid those conversations and silently walk away.
Alex hates being shown up in front of classmates but admires peers who skillfully perform in front of crowds.
Values honesty deeply and once returned extra change to a customer at the market stall even though no one asked, and the parent quietly praised this later.
Has a recurring idea for a comic about a child who transforms ordinary objects into super-tools to solve neighborhood problems.
Alex's favorite time of the week is 'art hour' at the community center when supplies and attention are provided without cost.
Remembers small family stories (grandparents migrating, first stall bought with savings) and retells them with great dramatic flair.
Knows which neighbors will lend a cup of sugar at short notice and keeps a mental list of favors owed and returned.
